text:
<@UJN1TAYEQ> It's an important issue, but it has been discussed here now and then (without finding a solution of course). Not sure that this suffices to make it trivial!
<@UC2A2ARPT> GraalVM is one attempt to address this issue, like other multi-language VMs (.NET for example) at a less ambitious level. They shift the problem from the language to the VM level. The VM still imposes a world view that may not fit some particular language.

elements.text: It's an important issue, but it has been discussed here now and then (without finding a solution of course). Not sure that this suffices to make it trivial!

GraalVM is one attempt to address this issue, like other multi-language VMs (.NET for example) at a less ambitious level. They shift the problem from the language to the VM level. The VM still imposes a world view that may not fit some particular language.

text:
> I think we don't talk nearly enough about marketing, adoption, etc.
After you start getting adoption, you also get feedback from users about what actually trips them up in your newfangled language.

Only been in the community for a bit, but it doesn't seem like we do a lot of watching how people learn to code. There's some 'observing what bugs people actually write', but probably still not enough.

Seeing what gets people excited, confused, motivated, etc. about current languages (especially as they learn them for the first time) is  powerful. If anyone wants to help someone with a problem over live chat, <http://pythontutor.com/> is up 24/7 with people asking for help...

text: It's not all the simple things, only those with many clearly different but not necessarily better alternatives.
